definition: Iterative approach to software development emphasizing flexibility and collaboration.
example: Our team adopted Agile to deliver features faster through sprints.

definition: Framework for Agile project management with roles like Scrum Master.
example: In Scrum, daily stand-ups help keep the team aligned on priorities.

definition: System for managing changes to source code over time.
example: We use Git for version control to track all code modifications.

definition: Restructuring code without changing its external behavior.
example: Refactoring the legacy code improved its readability and performance.

definition: Testing individual components of software in isolation.
example: Unit testing ensures each function works correctly before integration.

definition: Practice of merging code changes frequently into a shared repository.
example: Continuous integration with Jenkins automates our build process.

definition: Set of rules for building and interacting with software applications.
example: The RESTful API allows our frontend to fetch user data seamlessly.

definition: Process of finding and fixing errors in code.
example: Debugging the null pointer exception took most of the afternoon.

definition: Programming paradigm based on objects and classes.
example: Object-oriented programming in Java helps model real-world entities.

definition: Reusable solution to common problems in software design.
example: We applied the Singleton design pattern for database connection management.

definition: Systematic examination of code by peers for quality.
example: Code review caught a potential security vulnerability early.

definition: Technique for achieving inversion of control in applications.
example: Dependency injection makes our services more testable and modular.

definition: Architectural style composing application from small, independent services.
example: Migrating to microservices improved our scalability.

definition: Visual workflow management method for limiting work in progress.
example: Our Kanban board helps visualize tasks from backlog to done.

definition: Two developers working together at one workstation.
example: Pair programming accelerated our learning of the new framework.

definition: Time-boxed period in Agile to complete a set of work.
example: The two-week sprint focused on implementing user authentication.

definition: Prioritized list of work for the development team.
example: We groomed the product backlog before the sprint planning.

definition: Mechanism where a class acquires properties from another.
example: Inheritance allows the Child class to extend Parent functionality.

definition: Ability of objects to take multiple forms in programming.
example: Polymorphism enables method overriding for flexible code.

definition: Bundling data and methods within a class, hiding internals.
example: Encapsulation protects the object's state from unauthorized access.

definition: Computer that provides resources or services to clients.
example: The backend server handles all database queries efficiently.

definition: Architectural style for designing networked applications.
example: We built a REST API to expose our services to the frontend.

definition: Process of verifying user identity.
example: OAuth handles authentication for our third-party integrations.

definition: Determining user permissions after authentication.
example: Role-based authorization restricts access to admin features.

definition: Software that connects applications or components.
example: Express middleware processes requests before reaching routes.

definition: Storing data temporarily for quick access.
example: Redis caching reduced our database load significantly.

definition: Distributing incoming traffic across multiple servers.
example: NGINX load balancing ensures no single server is overwhelmed.

definition: Handling user sessions across requests.
example: We use JWT for stateless session management in our API.

definition: Query language for APIs to fetch exact data needed.
example: GraphQL replaced multiple REST calls with a single query.

definition: Protocol for full-duplex communication over a single TCP connection.
example: WebSocket enables real-time chat updates in our app.

definition: Data structure for asynchronous task processing.
example: RabbitMQ queue handles email notifications without blocking.

definition: Object-relational mapping tool for database interactions.
example: Hibernate ORM simplifies SQL operations in Java.

definition: Single entry point for managing multiple backend services.
example: Kong API Gateway routes traffic to our microservices.

definition: Controlling request frequency to prevent abuse.
example: Rate limiting protects our API from DDoS attacks.

definition: Converting objects into a storable format like JSON.
example: JSON serialization prepares data for API responses.

definition: Converting data from a storable format back to objects.
example: Deserialization parses incoming JSON into Java objects.

definition: Lightweight process for concurrent execution.
example: Multithreading improves server responsiveness under load.

definition: Mechanism to prevent concurrent access to shared resources.
example: Using a read-write lock avoids deadlocks in our code.

definition: Server acting as intermediary for client requests.
example: The reverse proxy forwards traffic to our backend servers.

definition: High-performance RPC framework using Protocol Buffers.
example: gRPC provides efficient communication between microservices.

definition: Markup language for structuring web content.
example: HTML forms collect user input for submission.

definition: Language for styling and layout of web pages.
example: CSS Flexbox simplifies responsive layout design.

definition: Programming language for interactive web pages.
example: JavaScript event listeners handle user clicks dynamically.

definition: JavaScript library for building user interfaces.
example: React components make UI reusable and maintainable.

definition: Designing websites to adapt to different screen sizes.
example: Responsive design ensures our site works on mobile devices.

definition: Document Object Model for representing HTML documents.
example: Manipulating the DOM updates the page without reload.

definition: Handling application data that changes over time.
example: Redux simplifies state management in large React apps.

definition: Module bundler for JavaScript applications.
example: Webpack bundles our assets for optimized loading.

definition: Designing for users with disabilities.
example: ARIA labels improve accessibility for screen readers.

definition: Web app with native-like features like offline support.
example: Our PWA allows users to install the site on their home screen.

definition: In-memory representation of the real DOM for efficient updates.
example: Virtual DOM in React minimizes direct manipulations.

definition: Functions for adding state and lifecycle in functional components.
example: useState hook manages local component state easily.

definition: CSS preprocessor with variables and nesting.
example: SASS variables make theming straightforward.

definition: Transpiler for converting modern JS to browser-compatible code.
example: Babel transpiles ES6+ features for older browsers.

definition: Loading resources only when needed to improve performance.
example: Lazy loading images speeds up initial page load.

definition: Reusable piece of UI in modular frameworks.
example: The Button component is styled consistently across the app.

definition: Handles navigation between different views in SPAs.
example: React Router manages client-side routing seamlessly.

definition: Pre-built structure for developing applications.
example: Vue.js framework accelerates frontend development.

definition: Visual effects to enhance user experience.
example: CSS animations provide smooth transitions between states.

definition: CSS framework for quick responsive prototyping.
example: Bootstrap grid system layouts our dashboard quickly.

definition: Apple's mobile operating system for iPhones.
example: Swift is the primary language for iOS app development.

definition: Open-source OS for mobile devices by Google.
example: Kotlin enhances Android development productivity.

definition: Digital marketplace for mobile applications.
example: Submitting to the App Store requires App Review compliance.

definition: Google's distribution platform for Android apps.
example: Optimizing for Google Play increases app discoverability.

definition: User Interface and User Experience design principles.
example: Prioritizing UI/UX leads to higher user retention.

definition: App built for a specific platform using its SDK.
example: Native apps offer better performance than hybrids.

definition: App using web technologies wrapped in a native shell.
example: Ionic builds hybrid apps with a single codebase.

definition: Message sent to user device from server.
example: Push notifications re-engage users with timely alerts.

definition: App functionality without internet connectivity.
example: Offline mode caches data for seamless user experience.

definition: User interaction via touch or motion.
example: Swipe gestures navigate between app screens intuitively.

definition: Modular UI component in Android apps.
example: Fragments allow dynamic UI changes without activity restarts.

definition: Single screen with user interface in Android.
example: The MainActivity launches when the app starts.

definition: Visual tool for designing iOS app interfaces.
example: Storyboard connects scenes for app flow visualization.

definition: Apple's declarative UI framework for Swift.
example: SwiftUI previews speed up iOS UI development.

definition: Modern toolkit for Android UI in Kotlin.
example: Jetpack Compose uses composables for reactive UIs.

definition: Connecting mobile app to backend services.
example: Retrofit simplifies API integration in Android.

definition: Accessing device GPS for geolocation.
example: Location services enable map features in our ride-sharing app.

definition: Using fingerprints or face ID for secure login.
example: Biometric authentication secures sensitive app data.

definition: Developing for multiple platforms with one codebase.
example: Flutter enables cross-platform mobile development efficiently.

definition: Framework for building native apps using React.
example: React Native compiles to native code for performance.

definition: Language for managing relational databases.
example: SQL queries retrieve specific records from tables.

definition: Non-relational database for unstructured data.
example: MongoDB is a popular NoSQL database for JSON-like documents.

definition: Data structure to speed up query retrieval.
example: Creating an index on the email column improves search speed.

definition: Unique identifier for each record in a table.
example: The user_id serves as the primary key in our users table.

definition: Field referencing primary key in another table.
example: The order table's customer_id is a foreign key to users.

definition: Process to reduce data redundancy in relational DBs.
example: Third normal form eliminates repeating groups in our schema.

definition: Intentionally introducing redundancy for performance.
example: Denormalization speeds up read-heavy reporting queries.

definition: Combining rows from two or more tables based on conditions.
example: An INNER JOIN links orders to customers by ID.

definition: Unit of work ensuring ACID properties.
example: Bank transfers use transactions to maintain consistency.

definition: Properties for reliable database transactions: Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability.
example: ACID compliance ensures data integrity during failures.

definition: Horizontal partitioning of data across multiple databases.
example: Sharding user data by region scales our system horizontally.

definition: Copying data to multiple servers for availability.
example: Master-slave replication provides read scalability.

definition: Improving SQL query efficiency.
example: EXPLAIN helps in query optimization by showing execution plans.

definition: Copy of data for recovery purposes.
example: Daily backups protect against data loss events.

definition: Recovering data from a backup.
example: We restore the database from last night's backup after corruption.

definition: Structure defining tables and relationships in a database.
example: The schema includes entities like users and posts.

definition: Virtual table based on SQL query results.
example: A view simplifies complex joins for reporting.

definition: Code that automatically executes on database events.
example: A trigger logs changes to audit sensitive tables.

definition: Precompiled SQL code stored in the database.
example: Stored procedures reduce network traffic for complex operations.

definition: Principle stating trade-offs in distributed systems: Consistency, Availability, Partition tolerance.
example: NoSQL databases often prioritize AP over C in CAP theorem.

definition: Amazon Web Services, cloud computing platform.
example: We host our application on AWS EC2 instances.

definition: Platform for containerizing applications.
example: Docker containers ensure consistent environments across dev and prod.

definition: Orchestration system for managing containers.
example: Kubernetes automates deployment and scaling of our microservices.

definition: Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment pipeline.
example: Jenkins implements our CI/CD for automated releases.

definition: Infrastructure as Code for provisioning resources.
example: Terraform manages our IaC for cloud infrastructure.

definition: Automatically adjusting resources based on demand.
example: Auto-scaling groups handle traffic spikes during sales.

definition: Virtual Private Cloud for isolated networking.
example: Our VPC secures communication between services.

definition: Amazon Simple Storage Service for object storage.
example: We store user uploads in S3 buckets with versioning.

definition: Serverless compute service for running code.
example: AWS Lambda triggers functions on S3 uploads.

definition: Observing system performance and health.
example: Prometheus provides monitoring for our Kubernetes clusters.

definition: Recording events for debugging and auditing.
example: ELK stack centralizes logging from all services.

definition: Deployment strategy with parallel environments for zero downtime.
example: Blue-green deployment switches traffic after validation.

definition: Gradual rollout to a subset of users.
example: Canary release tests new features on 5% of traffic.

definition: Automation tool for configuration management.
example: Ansible playbooks provision servers idempotently.

definition: Open-source CI/CD automation server.
example: Jenkins pipelines build and test code on commits.

definition: Package manager for Kubernetes applications.
example: Helm charts deploy complex apps with ease.

definition: AWS service for modeling infrastructure as code.
example: CloudFormation stacks create repeatable environments.

definition: Computing without managing servers.
example: Serverless architecture reduces operational overhead.

definition: Content Delivery Network for faster asset distribution.
example: CloudFront CDN caches static files globally.

definition: Using Git for declarative infrastructure management.
example: GitOps principles automate deployments via pull requests.

definition: Network security system blocking unauthorized access.
example: The firewall prevents inbound traffic from suspicious IPs.

definition: Converting data to secure format unreadable without key.
example: AES encryption protects sensitive data at rest.

definition: Fraudulent attempt to obtain sensitive information via email.
example: Employee training reduces risks from phishing attacks.

definition: Virtual Private Network for secure remote access.
example: Using VPN encrypts traffic over public Wi-Fi.

definition: Multi-Factor Authentication for added security.
example: MFA requires password plus a one-time code.

definition: Distributed Denial of Service attack flooding resources.
example: Cloudflare mitigates DDoS attacks effectively.

definition: Attack inserting malicious SQL via input fields.
example: Prepared statements prevent SQL injection vulnerabilities.

definition: Exploit for unknown vulnerability before patch.
example: Zero-day exploits target unpatched software flaws.

definition: Simulated cyberattack to find vulnerabilities.
example: Annual penetration testing identifies security gaps.

definition: Intrusion Detection System monitoring for threats.
example: Snort IDS alerts on suspicious network patterns.

definition: Intrusion Prevention System blocking detected threats.
example: IPS actively drops malicious packets in real-time.

definition: One-way function for data integrity and passwords.
example: bcrypt hashing secures user passwords in the database.

definition: Protocols for secure communication over networks.
example: HTTPS uses SSL/TLS to encrypt web traffic.

definition: Malware encrypting files for ransom payment.
example: Regular backups mitigate ransomware recovery costs.

definition: Manipulating people to divulge confidential information.
example: Phishing is a common social engineering tactic.

definition: Process of updating software to fix vulnerabilities.
example: Automated patch management keeps systems secure.

definition: Using biological traits for authentication.
example: Fingerprint biometrics secure mobile logins.

definition: Adhering to legal and regulatory standards.
example: GDPR compliance requires data protection measures.

definition: Investigating security incidents for evidence.
example: Digital forensics recovers data from compromised systems.

definition: Security Information and Event Management system.
example: Splunk SIEM correlates logs for threat detection.

definition: Computing model inspired by biological neurons.
example: Deep neural networks power image recognition tasks.

definition: ML where model trains on labeled data.
example: Supervised learning classifies emails as spam or not.

definition: ML finding patterns in unlabeled data.
example: Unsupervised learning clusters customers by behavior.

definition: Model learning noise instead of underlying pattern.
example: Regularization prevents overfitting in our models.

definition: Model too simple to capture data patterns.
example: Increasing model complexity avoids underfitting.

definition: Open-source ML framework by Google.
example: TensorFlow builds scalable deep learning models.

definition: Dynamic neural network library by Facebook.
example: PyTorch's flexibility aids rapid prototyping.

definition: Creating informative input variables for models.
example: Feature engineering boosts prediction accuracy.

definition: Configuration variable not learned from data.
example: Tuning learning rate hyperparameter optimizes training.

definition: Optimization algorithm minimizing loss function.
example: Stochastic gradient descent trains models efficiently.

definition: Deep learning for processing grid-like data like images.
example: CNNs excel at object detection in photos.

definition: Neural network for sequential data processing.
example: RNNs predict next words in text generation.

definition: ML learning through trial and error with rewards.
example: Reinforcement learning trains agents for games like chess.

definition: Balancing model complexity to avoid under/overfitting.
example: Cross-validation helps manage bias-variance tradeoff.

definition: Grouping similar data points without labels.
example: K-means clustering segments market data.

definition: Tree-like model for decisions and predictions.
example: Decision trees visualize classification logic clearly.

definition: Ensemble of decision trees for robust predictions.
example: Random forest reduces overfitting in ensemble learning.

definition: Natural Language Processing for understanding human language.
example: NLP powers chatbots for customer support.

definition: AI enabling machines to interpret visual data.
example: Computer vision detects defects in manufacturing lines.

definition: Using pre-trained models for new tasks.
example: Transfer learning fine-tunes models with less data.

definition: Specific condition to verify functionality.
example: Each test case covers edge scenarios in login.

definition: Retesting to ensure new changes don't break old features.
example: Automated regression testing runs after every deployment.

definition: Test for individual software components.
example: JUnit framework runs our unit tests efficiently.

definition: Testing interaction between integrated modules.
example: Integration tests verify API endpoints with databases.

definition: Preliminary test to check basic functionality.
example: Smoke tests confirm the build is stable post-deployment.

definition: Testing system under expected heavy load.
example: JMeter simulates load tests for peak traffic.

definition: Evaluating speed, scalability, and stability.
example: Performance testing identifies bottlenecks in code.

definition: Defect in software causing incorrect behavior.
example: The bug caused crashes on certain Android versions.

definition: Writing tests before implementing code.
example: TDD ensures code meets requirements from the start.

definition: Tool for automating web browser interactions.
example: Selenium scripts test end-to-end user flows.

definition: Simulated object replacing real dependencies in tests.
example: Mocks isolate unit tests from external services.

definition: Percentage of code executed by tests.
example: Aiming for 80% coverage ensures thorough testing.

definition: Unscripted testing to discover defects.
example: Exploratory testing uncovers usability issues missed by scripts.

definition: Validating if system meets business requirements.
example: User acceptance testing confirms feature readiness.

definition: Using software to run tests without human intervention.
example: Test automation speeds up repetitive validation tasks.

definition: Logging and monitoring bugs through resolution.
example: Jira handles defect tracking for our team.

definition: Testing at edges of input ranges.
example: Boundary testing checks max and min values.

definition: Evaluating ease of use with real users.
example: Usability testing refines intuitive navigation.

definition: Identifying vulnerabilities in the application.
example: OWASP tools aid security testing for web apps.

definition: Comparing two versions to determine better performance.
example: A/B testing optimizes button colors for clicks.

definition: Single, unified application structure.
example: Starting with a monolith simplifies initial development.

definition: Ability to handle increased load.
example: Horizontal scalability adds servers for growth.

definition: Uptime percentage ensuring system accessibility.
example: 99.9% availability means less than 9 hours downtime yearly.

definition: Delay before receiving a response.
example: Reducing latency improves user satisfaction.

definition: Rate of successful message delivery.
example: High throughput handles millions of requests per second.

definition: Small, independent services composing an application.
example: Microservices allow independent deployment of features.

definition: Architecture responding to events asynchronously.
example: Event-driven systems decouple producers and consumers.

definition: Command Query Responsibility Segregation for read/write separation.
example: CQRS optimizes queries with denormalized views.

definition: Unified entry point for backend services.
example: API Gateway handles authentication and routing.

definition: Pattern preventing cascading failures in distributed systems.
example: Hystrix circuit breaker stops calls to failing services.

definition: Dedicated infrastructure layer for microservices.
example: Istio service mesh manages traffic and security.

definition: Distributing data across multiple databases.
example: Sharding by user ID scales write operations.

definition: In-memory store for frequently accessed data.
example: Redis caching layer reduces database hits.

definition: Asynchronous communication between services.
example: Kafka message queue decouples order processing.

definition: Distributes traffic across multiple servers.
example: HAProxy load balancer ensures even distribution.

definition: Operations producing same result if repeated.
example: Idempotent APIs handle retries without side effects.

definition: Compensating transactions in distributed systems.
example: Saga pattern manages long-running workflows reliably.

definition: Design isolating core logic from external concerns.
example: Hexagonal architecture promotes testable code.

definition: Approach focusing on core business domain.
example: DDD models complex domains with aggregates.

definition: Storing state changes as sequence of events.
example: Event sourcing enables full audit trails of actions.
